comments.commentBody:
I think that Michael Bloomberg has done a good job as New York's mayor. I also favor Bill de Blasio to succeed Bloomberg, as I think that the city would benefit from the recalibrating that de Blasio would set in motion.

New York City is a big, flexible place. There's room to support and celebrate both Bloomberg and de Blasio and their diverse approaches to public policy.
I guess that would be if you made it into a good school...are at least into a good teacher's class. if not, it's a waste of time.

On-line courses remove ego, the Prof's and the students'. On-line Professors sound like salesmen. The affected voice, the artificial game. Students who respond on-line with questions or committed papers can be freed some by a sense of anonymity. Like talking into a mirror. Dimensions
of intellectual possibility, though, are diminished.

On-line can serve the spread of information. But when I taught
I had to continually guage the receptiveness or rejection in the
faces of my students. Sometimes the rejection was really skeptical receptivity. And vice versa, students willing to get into the human mix.
The classroom is a dance. Profs who lecture from age old notes have always been referred to as "deadwood," no matter how charming. How tenure gets a bad rep. The preppie, charming stuff is OK for freshmen, a form of post-prep guidance through school tradition into the atheist sophomore year when Profs are no longer gods and one had better be challenging for the students there to stretch their minds, not collect passing grades. At some point a great course becomes creative, not merely reactive. It becomes collaborative, arguments internecine, and cannot be predicted to happen. A fine Prof has a better percentage of making this happen, at least in Literature and the Humanities; it is personal,
professional, and more intimate in classroom time-share than on-line can be. On- line is great for passing on info. Synchretic, dialectic, eclectic, imaginary it ain't.

You are correct. I went to the desegregated schools in Charlotte and had a positive experience. I remember the lawsuit in the 90s which concerned a child not getting chosen in the magnet school lottery. After winning the suit and  upending years of work and successful desegregation the family packed up and left town. One thing that made desegregation so successful in the 79s was a firm commitment from families that could easily afford private school to send their children to public schools and to advocate for all students. Sadly, that is no longer the case in Charlotte.

Please do not make blanket statements. In spite of the recent retro events in North Carolina there are many well educated.0, progressive and enlightened folks in the state who believe in equality and unity.

Indians are often assumed to be a model minority. Many who come here are educated and like other immigrants before them enjoy higher social standing in many cases than blacks. It might surprise you that Italians used  to be considered non-white by the US government, but they assimilated and became  or were declared white.

How long do you stay with your preschooler/young child at drop-off at day-care or school if they are upset or having a tantrum and don't want you to leave?

I actually have some suggestions:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2ctCRtR1E4Q

http://www.proactiveconnections.com/yippee-yahoo.html
The school children should rejoice that you are retired.

Guess what? Your brilliant adult children are exactly like the brilliant adult children who are the product of your average school. It's just as easy to say that your children are who they are in spite of, not because of, your homeschooling.

Where's the evidence to the contrary?
You're a doctor who believes that mental illness is caused by poor parenting. That's why you're an anesthesiologist: lots of money for no patient interaction.

President Obama is finally taking a step in the right direction, but for all the wrong reasons: if it hadn't been for John Kerry's highly embarrassing but nonetheless very welcome blunder, the U.S. would undoubtedly have continued to push for a military strike from which we would have little to gain. (Indeed, how would we be advancing our "national interests" by intervening in a country where al-Qaeda-linked rebels and a Syrian regime supported by Iran, Russia, and Hezbollah kill each other?)

But even if Obama wisely decides not to strike, his unwillingness to rule out the possibility of a military strike without the authorization of Congress should be troubling to all of us. President Obama could do with taking a leaf out of Senator Obama's book: "The president does not have power under the Constitution to unilaterally authorize a military attack in a situation that does not involve stopping an actual or imminent threat to the nation."

The comments here represent desperate attempts to salvage Obama.

Putin has been his best Secretary of State so far. Sets stage for negotiations, helps nations back off from the brink of a bigger war, unites world opinion with a possible pathway to peace.

Hmmm. Who deserves the Nobel Peace Prize?

Banjo's comments are exactly on-point: it is wishful thinking to read this situation as anything other than the administration tripping on its shoelaces and finding a $100 bill stuck to its shoes.  Shows great promise for their future handling of Iran as well.

One stumble by an inept president on the world stage.

One poke in the eye from Putin.
Actually Kerry is that inept on his own.
Dont plan the parade just yet, my friend.
We owe Putin our gratitude!  He just saved us from WWIII.
How come we aren't stopping civil wars in the African nations then??
Assad should also step down and turn himself and his officers over to the Hague  to be tried for war crimes.

If it sounds too good to be true then it probably is. It is doubtful this will achieve the objective of maintaining US credibility and contain Syrian chemical weapon proliferation.

To establish this "International Monitors" effectively and not just in name only would require a degree of cooperation and commitment of resources not likely achievable. If the past UN peacekeeping forces are precedents, this "International Monitor" will likely be given a mandate without power. Its resources limited by economics of participating Nations. Its actions will be restricted by bureaucratic in-fighting.

The most concrete achievement would be to protect Syria from an attack, give Russia significant influence over Middle East events and give cover for Mr Obama for not attacking. Again, it is a lose option for the United States.

In the meantime, it will likely be "business as usual" for Assad while this "International Monitor" force is formed, rules of engagement negotiated and its resources being solicited; a lengthy tedious process.

It just sound too good be true but will be quickly embraced by those who seek a way out of their boxed in position.
Trust me, those of us in Europe are quite capable of handling our own affairs without the intervention of the USA. It's time the USA quietly packed up all of its toys and went home.

William Nash: Agree with your assessment on the USA military returning to its American bases.  However, based on recent history, highly doubtful of your assessment of Europe, its military capability or its collective will. One could argue with your conclusion.

Translation:  We (the US ) are not going to attack Syria. Due to the inaction of Western Europe, NATO will soon be dismantled.  American troops will return to our continent, and Western Europe will fester in the environment they have brought upon themselves.  And if something equivalent to the March 20, 1995, sarin gas attack on the Tokyo, Japan subway system by Aum Shinriyko occurs, due to proximity of the stockpile of Syrian gas, somewhat likely on the European continent, European NATO will at  be forced to reassess their inaction and their disloyalty to their North American allies.
Still better than the joke known as G W. Bush.

Hozeking;
Don't be naive; Putin is as ruthless as his U.S counterparts !!!
Conscious- you really believe Obama is as ruthless as Putin?
This is where Obama has brought us. Russia leads, and UAS follows.

Saddam Hussein was tyrant compared to whom Nero was an enlightened philanthropist. Chemicals were his weapon of choice. He possessed them and used them. Thanks to President Bush, we haven't heard much from him for some time.

This Assad, bad as he is, is of far lesser magnitude -- and certainly preferable to the Islamists waiting to replace him, and whom Obama is enabling.

Meanwhile, Obama has nurtured Iran to the brink of nuclear weaponhood, and no one seems to care.

Almost all the evidence is circumstantial. A case is not sent to the court because the proof is only spoken of as being real . It isn't enough to get a conviction.
But trust your president cuz he says so.

Finally a voice of reason. Thank you for not wasting your gifts defending Obama.

Admittedly Putin is a thug and is poking Obama and Kerry in the eye, but at least he is enough of a world player to put forward a clever and useful strategy for dealing with chemical weapons and- who knows– perhaps setting the stage for exploring a political solution.

I believe Obama had to make a credible threat before the alternative could be suggested, and it had to be suggested by Russia, or perhaps a Middle Eastern state.  Iran couldn't do it, probably not Saudi Arabia either. I think they are playing a masterful chess game here to get a peaceful solution desired all along--perhaps not achievable, but if not due to Syria, not the U.S.

Obama's threat of military action is definitely the reason Putin has pursued containing the CW. But that was not because of any US strategy.

If Obama's goal was to secure the weaponry, he would have proposed that Syria allow the weapons to be secured or there would be an attack. Or he would have tired to lobby foreign powers to support getting the weapons secured. Either way,the world and the American public would have supported him.

Instead, Obama sought support to bomb Syria willy nillly with who knows what damage to civilians. In his typical paternalistic fashion, he was going to give Assad a "spanking".

In even more typical Amer. fashion, all the US public and Congress could see was how this would affect the US. Read the commentators here to see the mindset.

Putin understood that Obama\s and the US's complete parochialism, arrogance and incompetence AND the domino effect an attack could have that could set the region on fire with enormous economic and political consequences for the world.

It doesn't matter if the weapons are secured or there are years of negotiations. Putin has brought everyone back from the precipice.

Hopefully, now the US can partner with Russia, giving respect to Russia's interest in Syria, and end the conflict.

I believe that you are wrong.

We have had enough of war.

The world will not address this situation as forcefully and immediately as you wish. Enough people in the world know the risks and brutality of war.

We are not the policemen of the world. We have enough to accomplish here at home.

I applaud Russia's proposal that Syria turn over its chemical weapons stock to the United Nations, as well as President Obama's support for the concept. This is a win-win solution for all involved:
--The UN is strengthened.
--Both the U.S. and Russia can legitimately claim victory.
--Foreign military intervention in Syria is avoided.
--The people of Syria are safer.
--A basis is laid for the use of diplomacy to negotiate an end to Syria's civil war.

I hope that the Russian proposal will form the basis of a solution to The use of chemical weapons in Syria.
